data.title: cython-based C++-/Python interface
data.body:
- openage is now a shared library
- moved `py/openage` -> `openage`
- moved `py/openage/codecompliance` -> `buildsystem/codecompliance`
- moved `cpp/` -> `libopenage/`
- moved `doc/implementation/` -> `doc/code`
- integrated Cython into buildsystem
- C++ -> Py function calling
  - C++ API is specified in PXD annotations in `.h` files
  - cpp/pyinterface/pyfunc.h
  - Func<returntype, arg0type, arg1type, ...>
  - Callable objects
  - Designed to be filled with pointers to cdef functions
  - **don't use raw function pointers in the interface**
  - openage/cppinterface/setup.py
  - setup() Fills the PyFunc pointers
  - must be called before using libopenage functionality
- Exception translation
  - cpp/pyinterface/exctranslate.h
  - translate_exc_cpp_to_py
  - translate_exc_py_to_cpp
  - py/cppinterface/exctranslate.py
  - describe_exception
  - raise_cpp_error
  - C++ functions that are declared 'except +' if they may throw
  - Python functions that are declared 'except *' if they may raise
  - GIL-safe
  - everything is translated back and forth
  - metadata
  - message
  - backtrace
- Documentation

C++:
- Overhauled exception code
  - now lives in `error/error.h`
  - exceptions automatically store their cause exception
  - exceptions can collect backtraces
  - see demo in `cpp/error/demo.cpp`
  - Hierarchies may now be used
  - `doc/code/exceptions`
- Moved util/error.h to error/error
- Added error/handlers.cpp, which provides a SIGSEGV and terminate handler
- refactored LZXD code
  - removed many C-isms and micro-optimizations
  - simplified codeflow, split methods into smaller ones
  - file split into multiple smaller ones (`cpp/util/compress`)
  - `decompress` replaced by `decompress_frame`, which decompresses just
    32768 bytes at a time instead of everything at once.
  - exposed to Python using the PyInterface
- Simplified C++ logging
  - ExternalStringStream: like stringstream, but appends to a custom buffer
- Modernized C++ testing
  - now uses TestError (e.g. via the `TESTFAIL` macro) instead of return values.
- C++ exceptions can collect backtraces
- `SIGSEGV` and `std::terminate` handlers
- Enum class that allows adding new members at runtime, and associated data.
  - used by `log::lvl`
- `util/init.h`: `OnInit` and `OnDeInit`: to call functions on dynamic initialization
- fixed a bug with Timer

Python:
- Bumped Python version requirement to 3.4
- Massive clean-up
  - Unified all utility modules into the openage.util package
  - Removed some code that got obsoleted in the process
  - Made stuff more pylint-compliant
  - Replaced home-brewn Enum and NamedObject implementations by enum.Enum
- Implemented some utilities
  - openage/util/fslike.py
  - FileSystemLikeObject abstract base class
  - Directory FileSystemLikeObject
  - openage/util/filelike.py
  - FileLikeObject abstract base class
  - StreamSeekBuffer FileLikeObject
  - StreamFragment FileLikeObject
  - FIFO FileLikeObject
  - FSLikeObject used by convert and codegen
- Overhauled testing system
  - openage.testing.testing.assert_result
  - openage.testing.testing.assert_raises
  - openage.testing.testing.TestError
  - now done without CTest
  - C++ and Python tests and demos all called via Python
- Integrated cabextract/cab.py with the rest of the project
  - now a FileSystemLikeObject
  - takes a FileLikeObject as an argument
  - added tests
- PEFile has been refactored
  - resource strings are now resolved
  - the code uses NamedStructs
- The Python logger now forwards to the C++ logger if the interface has been
  initialized
  - Central management of current loglevel
  - `--verbose`, `--quiet`
- Program has one single entry point: `openage.__main__.main()`
  - run with `python3 -m openage`
  - alternatively: `./run`
  - subcommands: `game`, `test`, `codegen`
- Media file conversion is now done when launching the game.

Buildsystem:
- added valgrind-python.supp, a valgrind suppression file.
- added basic whitespace compliance checking for textfiles
- added pylint code compliance checking
  - Many files are not yet pylint-compliant; those have a header
    '# TODO pylint: disable=C,R,whatever categories'
- added selective code compliance checking (closes #229)
- re-worked Makefile targets

closes #217 

See the various doc files, including [pyinterface](https://github.com/mic-e/openage/blob/pyinterface/doc/code/pyinterface.md), [testing](https://github.com/mic-e/openage/blob/pyinterface/doc/code/testing.md)

Some things are still remaining to do, but they in no way prevent merging:
- write interface for `FSLikeObject`
  - use that interface for all asset handling (in C++)
  - add `inotify` support to `FSLikeObject`
- support for other sources for `openage.convert` (setup disk/.iso #82)

Note: If you wish to start work that derives from this before it's been merged, which you should, if you're about to start any new branch, base it on [this commit](https://github.com/mic-e/openage/commit/483c482649fa026cee8fe4024237f34f23255ab3). That commit is guaranteed to end up as-is in `openage/master`.

data.title: [WIP] New renderer
data.body:
This is basically a totally new graphics engine, designed for our needs.
- [X] Abstraction of render backend
- [X] OpenGL 3.3 requirement
- [X] Preparations for Vulkan (we don't know much..)
- [X] File watching subsystem
- [X] `constexpr` key-value map
- [X] Screenshot support
  - [ ] optimizations (maybe [this](http://www.songho.ca/opengl/gl_pbo.html#pack) or [this](http://www.opengl-tutorial.org/intermediate-tutorials/tutorial-14-render-to-texture/))
- [ ] Render pipeline abstraction
  - [X] Textures
  - [X] Shaders
  - [x] Compiletime shader variable access
    - [x] Uniforms
    - [x] Vertex attributes
    - [x] Dynamic buffer uploading
  - [ ] Samplers
  - [ ] Materials
  - [ ] Geometries
- [x] Quaternions
- [ ] Texture position transformations without reuploading vertex buffer
- [ ] Texture packing
  - [ ] Efficient binpacking
  - [ ] 3D Textures
- [ ] Separate renderer thread and other event loop improvements
- [ ] Efficient render task queuing (minimize shader/texture changes)
  - [ ] Viewport clipping
- [ ] Smooth zooming
- [ ] Enable Z-Buffering
- [ ] Geometry drawing
  - [ ] squares
  - [ ] circles
  - [ ] smooth paths
  - [ ] boxes (for the gui)
  - [ ] text rendering (use freetype / harfbuzz / pango)
- [ ] Perspective translation (e.g. the unit-selected-circle)
- [ ] Terrain rendering
  - [ ] Terrain texture merging to single square tile
  - [ ] Perspective rendering
  - [ ] Blending cache
  - [ ] Terrain blending in the shader (in perspective to easily split tiles)
- [ ] Outline rendering with obstruction dual-pass (z-flip)
- [ ] [Occlusion](https://a248.e.akamai.net/f/248/10/10/http.developer.nvidia.com/GPUGems/gpugems_ch29.html) [queries](http://vertostudio.com/gamedev/?p=177)
- [ ] Pixel-perfect unit hitbox for unit selection and damage areas

implements #34, #286 and ideas from #153 
closes #264 (file watching subsystem).
will do #149 (terrain blending in shader), #158 /  #154 (blending cache), #141 (terrain perspective adjustments), #359 (outlines), #368 (unit selection box), #374 (texture clipping incorrect).

If you wanna work on this as well, submit pull requests to [my branch](https://github.com/TheJJ/openage/tree/renderer) please!

data.title: GameMain / Renderer design?
data.body:
`GameMain` could be broken into several components, I think splitting into model (terrain, units), view (main opengl rendering) and controller (hud/hotkeys) might work.

This would allow all the rendering code to be split into its own system, allowing easy future extensions (3d terrain or something)
The `UnitTypes` currently contain graphics, it maybe be better to remove these and have the renderer map `UnitTypes` to graphics which would allow easier graphic modding

data.title: Customizable key bindings
data.body:
I've started working on customizable key bindings, but would like some feedback on the design.
The key bindings are structured as follows: 
- There's a `action_t` enum which lists all bindable actions.
- You can bind a `std::function` object to such actions. I used lambda expressions to replace the original switch statement.
- You'll be able to point from keys to actions. This is currently hardcoded, but will be saved in a file. 

There's still some open questions:
- Currently everything is for `SDL_KEYUP` events. It would be easy to extend this to also incluse `SDL_KEYDOWN` events, but do we need this? (we'll need key modifiers like control as well)
- The meaning of the current `y`, `z`, `x` and `c` key bindings is unclear. What do they do? It would be nice to document this, or remove them if they're not needed.

Implements the basics for #271

data.title: String resource markup format
data.body:
I stumbled over this comment in the converter source:

``` python
# TODO: transform and cleanup the read strings...
# (strip html, insert formatchars/identifiers, ...)
```

When take a look at the strings, the following format is being used:
- `<Team>`
- `<b>Mini-map<b>`
- `Create <b> Samurai<b> (<cost>)`
- ..

I see two different "features" in there. The first one is the pseudo-HTML (it's not HTML as no proper closing tags are being used) that's being used for markup. The other thing is placeholders.

My suggestion is the following:
- Use a markdown subset for markup: `*italic*`, `**bold**`, `***bold italic***`. Maybe also the underscore variants (although I prefer simplicity).
- Use a placeholder syntax inspired by Python 3's named `.format()` syntax: `Create **Samurai** ({cost})`. I don't think we need formatting syntax like `!s` or `:.2`.
- Convert all uppercase placeholders to lowercase. Convert camelCase (not sure if that even exists) to snake_case.
- Strip unneeded whitespace

So the examples above would become:
- `{team}`
- `**Mini-map**`
- `Create **Samurai** ({cost})`

An alternative placeholder could be like in the Django template language: `{{ placeholder_name }}`. That would also leave open the possibility for filters: `{{ begin_date|date:"d.m.y H:M" }}`

Opinions?

data.title: [WIP] Media versioning
data.body:
My attempt on versioning the media files. Introduces a data pack format (#86).

Basically, all converted and generated files will store some version (e.g. the gamedata specification hash). The engine can detect required/present discrepancies and trigger reconversion.

When this is merged, users won't have to reconvert everything for changes in one area only, but this will require #79 to be finished.

This implements and thus closes #204.

New features:
- [X] Hashing the exported struct member configuration
- [X] Simple mod data pack format
- [ ] Check if the compiled-in struct format hash == exported-gamedata-files-format-hash

data.title: Create file watching subsystem
data.body:
Currently, the inotify support is pretty proof-of-concept only. It's directly integrated into the assetmanager, which should be abstracted in the future.

I'm thinking of creating a `libopenage/watch/` subsystem which provides some sane api for registering a watch on a folder, file, etc with requested events.

When the watched events happen, generic callback functions should be called so we can use the watches for any file watching makes sense.

In the background, the "sane api" calls the plattform-specific kernel api, but openage can use just one uniform interface. This way we can support OS X, BSD, etc.

data.title: Proposal: Split header files to avoid include dependency hell
Abort on checkfull fail
data.body:
Currently, the sanity check is done before compiling, but the build doesn't abort if something is wrong.
That way, the error messages get burried before all the compilation output.

With this, Travis won't compile if checkfull fails.
Also, fancier IRC notification.

data.title: More Fixes
data.body:
Fixes:
- Ranged units no longer freeze trying to garrison
- Garrison restricted to allied buildings (and must be built)
- Siege can be placed on land not water now.
- Buildings take some time to train a unit.
- Units can ungarrison while a building is training something.
- Fix segfault when shuting down
